Title: Targeting Promoter Quadruplex Nucleic Acids for Cancer Therapy
Abstract: © 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.Quadruplex nucleic acids are formed by repetitive short tracts of guanine nucleotides folding into four-stranded structures. These sequences are found throughout the human genome but are overrepresented in the promoter sequences of a number of cancer-associated genes, notably in oncogenes such as c-. MYC and c-. KIT. Small molecules can bind to these sequences and stabilize the resulting quadruplex structures. As a consequence, transcription of the affected gene can be impaired, and also the presence of a quadruplex arrangement may elicit a local yet lethal DNA damage response and ultimately anticancer activity. This article describes the basis for quadruplex-targeted chemotherapy and focuses on surveying the small molecules that have been used as selective promoter quadruplex stabilizers.
